commentBody: *sighs in canadian*

Creating a flag is a banner achievement.

(Especially when it's in pole position.)

I haven't started on the Wednesday puzzle yet, but I wanted to give a shout out to....   I'm pretty sure it was Aaron in Iowa for recommending the Halloween day 2013 puzzle. That was so so cool!! I don't want to give away any spoilers on it but I will second the recommendation. I was just a little bit blown away!!

SAGUARO
NYRO
POME

Wake me up when these words aren’t so obscure (for we Canadians).

As I was filling in 2D, I got the thought that maybe a better clue might have been [Change one's Waze?].



Recalculating...
Loved it!  Great theme. Fun and unique clues answers all across the grid.  Hope to see more, Todd!

Okay, I guess it's been too long a day.  When I read the clue [How many TV hosts are dressed], my first thought was, "All of them, I think."  Of course, we never know what the situation is under the anchor desk.
Deb said she has been to none of these states.  I've been to all except Tennessee!  And I live in western Canada.  No idea about the flags, though.  What a zany theme.

I picked up on the stately theme easily enough, although, having no great familiarity with STATE FLAGS, I wasn’t aided by the number of stars in the ratings.  I did eventually guess that the ratings corresponded to the number of stars on the respective flags, but by then the puzzle was all but solved.

Once again, time spent with my grandson proved immensely helpful as he is a fan of Captain Underpants, and I have spent quite a bit of time reading books in that series to him.  I was also happy to get MOE right away.  My knowledge of rappers derives almost exclusively from crosswords.  Knowledge comes from unlikely sources sometimes, although I do wonder how much valuable information I’ve lost to make room for the vast amount of ephemera I’ve amassed over the years.
Surely the NYT gets better submissions than this?  INASUIT?  Seriously?

I forgot to mention my pleasure at seeing a reference to the wonderful songwriter Laura NYRO.  Like many I got to know her songs through cover versions, particularly some great ones by The Fifth Dimension.  It was great to discover her own versions when I was a little older.  Pity she died at 50.
I’ll never look at state flags the same way again!

I found this puzzle to be about average difficulty for a Wednesday but, is it just me, or were the state clues painfully easy? Kinda stole the theme’s thunder, in my mind.

I live in a one star state but it’s my favorite place on earth. Especially the Northern part. From Big Sur on up. 

Thanks for the fun puzzle, Todd Gross!

I admired how the "star ratings" increased as we went from top to bottom. 

This led me to look at images of the 50 state flags. A few others have one star (California, Minnesota, North Carolina, Texas). And some have more than Georgia's 13: Indiana, Ohio and Mississippi. Minnesota had 19 tiny stars until recently; now, it has one large 8-pointed star.

An Art of the State puzzle!  

Great fun, with clues that were all a little tilted to keep us guessing enough to make it challenging.

Thanks, Todd Gross.  Now that you're back on track, don't stay away so long.
I instantly thought of these other one star reviews: https://mymodernmet.com/national-park-review-posters-amber-share/
"ARIZONA’s state flag features only one star," but it's a very BIG star!  This puzzle was great fun!  Thank you, Todd Gross, for such a fun puzzle!

It wasn’t until I made it to Georgia that I realized the answers were just state names. Up to that point I was making it way too complicated trying to think of plays on film titles. (Like, is there a movie called Grand Canyon, and this answer will be Mediocre Canyon with a rebus?)
Anybody wanna help me understand 29A?  I got from the crossing clues, but I have no idea what it means.
An amp and a speaker are two different things.  I don't really get that one.

First the positives: Laura NYRO is a pretty wild singer and songwriter, hugely influential. Also liked seeing Kool MOE Dee in there. Interesting theme but could have been finessed a bit more. I liked the EAR and AMP clues.

Negatives: I got naticked in a few spots. I’m not familiar with Captain Underpants or The Thin Man. And never heard of Sydney SIDER. Seemed like most of the clues were either too easy or impossible for me without looking up stuff.

Total rating: 2 STARS
Calling CDL 450 is like saying that twenty-fourteen is 34

An important day for the world! Or, you know, just me. I finally got to a 200-day streak. I needed an alphabet run for the SAGUARO/NYRO crossing, but that doesn't count as cheating in my version of the game. The next big goal: a 365-day streak.

Interestingly, I've been to all the states mentioned today (my ratings of them would be quite different though).

Once I got to Georgia, it was pretty smooth traveling, although that NW corner did slow me down a bit. It took me a few to realize that calling a state a “big ditch” was not an insult, but rather a reference to the Grand Canyon. And that speaker clue… I was trying to come up with a 3-letter brand (JBL?), but never considered AMP because, um, no.

While I do feel for non-US solvers, I think US-centric puzzles like this are to be expected, given the publisher’s location. There are NYC-based clues all the time that I don’t know, but that’s also fair. At least people in Australia got one up on (many of) the US folks tonight!

I appreciated the Laura Nyro reference, as well as the nod to The Thin Man and Asta. Right now, I’m feeling a strong urge to go listen to “Poverty Train”, followed by a fun mystery caper with the Charleses. Thanks, Todd!
For anyone who is not familiar with SAGUAROs, I offer the (supposed true) story of David Grundman: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9_9LDLur5P4

This was quicker for me than yesterday's puzzle, if only by a minute, even though I only had a vague grasp of the theme at first. If I knew more about the US, I might have finished the puzzle in Monday-ish time. It may have been too easy for a Wednesday?
Maybe this is just me but today felt tough... And yet I solved it without having to go back and check for mistakes once the grid was filled. Challenging but enjoyable!
Put up more resistance than a typical Wednesday for me, which is a welcome change.

I can reassure Sam that a lot of her foreign solvership will be aware of the Grand Canyon, that Alaska's in the north and Georgia's always on my mind.

Philadelphia-based snack brands not so much...

NYT keeps clueing “nae” as some variety of “Scottish denial”, today it’s “Dundee denial”.

In Scots, “nae” is only used in place of no where it’s used to express a quantity. When used as a denial the word is “naw”. As in “huv ye goat ony bananas in the day?” [have you got any bananas in today?] “Naw, we’ve goat nae bananas at aw” [no, we’ve got no bananas at all].

While in English the two versions are the same word, in Scots, and by extension in the hybrid Scots/English spoken in Dundee and other places, they are two different words and nobody would respond to a yes/no question with “nae”.

While I’m usually the first one to complain about a puzzle being inaccessible for us non-US solvers, I found this one to be absolutely lovely, with clues being, at least in my opinion, general knowledge also globally.
Only when I solved the first part of the revealer did I realise the puzzle has yet another level to it, and I love it all the more for that. A pleasure,overall!
Another bit of subtlety: TENNESSEE's nickname is the Volunteer State. And of course there's the wonderful song GEORGIA On My Mind. Fun puzzle, clever theme!
Picking a nit here but…technically an amp is what powers the speaker. If it’s a guitar or bass amp it IS on stage. However, it is an entirely separate entity.

Well, that was different.  In a good way.  

As I sometimes do for kicks, I ignored the themed entries.  When they started to fill themselves in, I noticed that they were states and just went with it.  Going back to read the clues was a bonus at the end.  Nice one, Todd!
Well, I hope we don’t have to wait another 5 years for a puzzle from Todd.  This was a lot of fun and just right for a Wednesday.

The clue about salmon and scenery? I immediately tried to fit in Scotland/Speyside/Highlands somehow! Sadly much of Scottish salmon is farmed nowadays and they're not doing very well. 

As a child in Scotland, tinned salmon sandwiches were the absolute most luxurious treat for Hogmanay (NY Eve).

Crossword a little harder than Mon/Tues but not bad. Didn't know the snack company or the rapper and got everything else through the crossers again. 

What do people call 'cheating'? Revealing to me is cheating, but what about looking up eg names of sport stars? Anything US sports based I allow myself to reveal because just too many and too obscure.

That was fun. Bit of a workout for me as I wasn't catching on to a number of things just from the clues, but that just made for a nice challenge and a bunch of good 'aha' moments when I finally had enough crosses to work those out. 

And... will confess that I wasn't entirely catching on to what the stars had to do with it until after I was done and went back and reviewed. That just made for one nice last 'doh!' moment.

And... I've been to every state except Hawaii in my lifetime, though Alaska was just a brief stop-over on a flight. My dad took us on long driving trips every summer when I was growing up. 

And lastly - a brief answer history search led me to a Frances Hansen puzzle and the realization that...
GEORGIAONMYMIND
and
HOAGYCARMICHAEL

Are both 15 letters. 

I'm done. 

..

Well, if that ain’t a (fun) way
of making the theme 
a way to
speedskate through a puzzle,

I don’t know what is! 

Enjoyed every minute.

Gross!
Thank you!

I’m reminded of a fun fact we learned from a crossword puzzle a few years back. The state flag of ALASKA, which has eight gold STARS in the shape of the Big Dipper, was designed by a 13-year old living in an orphanage. 

Fun with flags! I get why Sheldon Cooper was so fascinated. I will probably go down a rabbit hole later today reading about state flags. 

And this is why I love crossword puzzles. You learn so much.

Thanks, Todd.
A little tougher than the average Wednesday, but no complaints. A nice challenge.

I couldn’t be gladder. After weeks in the nadirs, during which they made no sense, I attained a longed for goal. I glommed on to a puzzle theme! Oh my stars, what a state I’m in!
Hoo-Rah! I am the Altair, the prima donna, the Ramses I of puzzledom.

Ok sure, zip it, enough tralala already, the emu implies. It was an easy one. Let it rest. Methinks the lady, she fusses too much. 

The beastie is now giving me the Silent T(reatment).
But even Cruella couldn’t ruin my day today.

Six years ago, Todd came up with one of my favorite grid designs of all times – one that feels to me like it’s floating – worth a look, IMO: https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/game/daily/2016/06/18 . I love his creativity in coming up with today’s theme, equating state flag stars with review stars. That is one wacky brilliant leap. Regarding the fill-in, getting the states from their clues seemed easy to me, but there were plenty of answers that took plenty of crosses as well, and it took a while for me to crack what the theme was – and when I finally did, it was a sweet moment of “Hah!” and “Oh how clever!” Clues for the task of ironing often are punny (playing on words like “pressing” and “decrease”), but Todd, with [Working on a board, perhaps], came up with a terrific never-done-before one. Bravo on that! I also liked the PuzzPair© of SAGUARO and a backward ALIG, because both can be found in the Sonoran Desert. This puzzle drew me right in and when I was through I had that “This is why I love doing crosswords” feeling. Thank you so much for making this, Todd!

That was pretty hard for a little old Wednesday!

I took a while to catch the theme but enjoyed it when I did.

Things I did not know and/or like:

"rah" - seems really forced

"sider" - still have no idea about this; maybe some sports thing

"pome" - made an informed guess based on French apple

"olio" - have never seen that meaning

I knew Altair as an early home computer so that was fun to see.

Fun, tough puzzle, nice theme.  Three stars.  ;)

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

This puzzle was amusing as all getout!
Couple of points: 1D: Can anyone parse this so that an amp is a speaker? I don't think that's a great clue.
Also, 18A: Surprised that Sam was surprised by this one, as to me it seems to be a Crossword Cliché. Like, it's one of those filler words that I've *never* seen outside of puzzles.
But, yeah, I loved the theme.

My first thought reading the clue for 1A was that the revealer must be Subpar Parks. If you’re unfamiliar with their Instagram page, I highly recommend @Subparparks. They’re reviews that sound very much like 1A taken from people’s actual reviews of US National parks and landmarks. They’re hilarious. 

Anyway, I saw that Grand Canyon wouldn’t fit. Thought it could be a rebus. Looked for other starred clues and knew 67A immediately, since I live there! I found the themed clues easy, but didn’t know several Naticks. Didn’t get the music and realized I had entered SAGUARa instead of SAGUARO for 12D. Fun puzzle!

Gladder was I, ere I saw “TRALALA”.

And huge shout out for the hilarious burn in the column’s title!

I really enjoyed this puzzle - a bit more scrunchy than many recent Wednesdays, and the combination of the simple-to-figure-out states from their descriptions, but wondering how are they going to rescue or justify those viscous reviews of Arizona and Nevada?? Fun, for me at least, despite being a…

North-sider.

Have no idea what a Sydney SIDER is.  Is it offered at a fast food joint? 

We had fun solving this. And to those who carped about AMP. When I was the worst rhythm guitar player in upstate NY we called my Marshall.... drum roll an AMP.  Note: Marshall AMPs are biggily.

Thank you Todd, but you forgot Maine whose new state flag has a star.

SIDER looked weird, but a post-solve looked taught this Michigander that Sydneysider is the accepted demonym, and has been since 1865.

Stars are "members" of constellations, I suppose, but the clue to ALTAIR looked weird, too: did Mr. Gross not want to use the word "star" in a (non-themed) clue?

OLIO is one of those old-timey fill words which remind me of my childhood, working the Pee-Dee's Daily crossword--it ran opposite the comics page, just under "Goren on Bridge"--at my Mother's knee. Happy memories! So put that ort in your olla for safekeeping!

A happy morning reading about Roman numerals, and the taxonomy of fruiting bodies.
"Amp" is short for "amplifier". An amp is not a speaker, but it may contain one or more.
The moon is visible during the day as often as it is during the night

I was slightly too old for Captain Underpants when he hit the scene, so I didn't get TRALALA for quite a while. Give me a clue about Animorphs or Goosebumps! Cater specifically to my cultural knowledge, and no one else's, please!

Fun puzzle, five stars.

"That's so mean and so unfair, Todd," I'm thinking.  "What did ARIZONA ever do to you?"

Then it occurred to me: "But what if it's flag has only one star?"

And there it was right next door.  The revealer.  FLAGS.

Hey, how many stars does the flag of GEORGIA have anyway?  Too many to count -- at least for lazy ol' me.

This is a very cute idea for a puzzle and the cluing is quite playful.  It's also very clean with a minimum of names.  It's a puzzle I'd give to a newbie solver who I wanted to come back for more puzzles in the future.  It's not hard and it gets even easier once you catch on.  But it's breezy and a lot of fun.  Nice job.
a little biased to say the least but eastern Tennessee is definitely somewhere you should visit, the beauty of the smokies and appalachia is unmatched. lovely puzzle :)

Filled in, but no music, so I had to cycle through all my answers.  Before flyspecking I had not had to evaluate the clue for 27D: "Creator of the sleuth C. Auguste Dupin", but when I got to it I realized I had mispelled NESSON.  

Solid Wednesday puzzle with an interesting theme.
Hard for a Wednesday.

For newer solvers who want a good challenge, may I recommend the puzzle from Sunday, July 25, 2021, by Chandi Deitmer--who was (co-)constructor of this past Saturday's puzzle. It has a theme which ties into today's, and one of the theme entries in particular.

Very tricky--get your "Thursday Hats" on--but my all-time favorite NYT XW thus far.

he "review" for 67A gave me pause. Surely not the 13 STARS of the Confederate battle flag? Oh, I see now that the re-designed flag of GEORGIA has a ring of stars around the state seal. So now it just looks a lot like the other Confederate flag, AKA the Stars and Bars. Fun with FLAGS, indeed!

Oh yeah, I got the rapper's name today.

I never noticed the variety and number of stars on state flags before, thanks!

Alaska’s 8 are gold like the 5 on the flag of China, and most of Alaska’s stars have Arabic names… Alioth, Dubhe, Alkaid, Mizar, Merak, Phecda, and Megrez.  Polaris is a kinda modern adaptation from navigation.

Arkansas has 4 blue stars, one representing the Confederacy (!), as well as 25 white ones.  California has one red star, originating in an 1836 attempt at independence from Mexico.

Sheldon Cooper would be proud of me!

Easy...except ok...true confessions. I filled in "Deo" without hesitation for 23 across, and it took me quite a while to suss out that error. 
⭐ Tralala! Now I am gladder.

Strands comment.

SPOILER ALERT

Pangolins are not bipeds, they are quadrupeds.

For a while I thought maybe a rebus had been thrown at us on a Wednesday, but only for one square, and in an odd place. But I skipped that clue and kept going; good thing, too. Because the answer was ZIPIT,  not ZIPper, as I initially thought. Stuff like that happens when I read too fast. I initially had the adverb noir instead of the noun NUIT, and that helped to lead me astray. (Would you call a color an adverb? Discuss.) I think Noir was on my mind because we were at a restaurant in Florida last week (Mom's funeral...don't be sad, she was 103 and lived a wonderful life) and the restaurant was Cafe Noir. The cafe was quite memorable (in a good way), so that is what led me astray. (Excuses: I can manufacture them in my sleep!)
not to be pedantic but an amp is part of a speaker system but not a speaker itself.

I knew the subject of 40D when he was still Second Lieutenant Underpants.


I hear he was short-listed for Defense Secretary.

The clueing was a bit trickier than usual for a Wednesday. AMP (really?)held up the start until I figured out the theme. Had DEO before ALTAIR changed it. I didn’t remember the star but given enough letters I knew which one it was.  Having lived in that spectacular city, I knew Sydneysider but was surprised to see it in a Wednesday difficulty answer. It must be quite obscure to American solvers. 
I thought initially that this would be about funny Yelp reviews of National Parks.

I got Altair only because I recently ate at the surprisingly-fantastic restaurant by that name in midtown Manhattan. 

Definitely a star worth adding to the cross-country road (flight) trip.

Let’s see if this comment A) gets posted, and B) stays posted. I’ve either been getting blocked or removed recently despite having done nothing offensive. 

I liked the puzzle. Got a little hung up in the NE. Is “sider” truly a suffix? Is it not just one half of a compound noun?

Just came here to see if anyone else was unfamiliar with "Sydneysider". It's legit; I'd just never heard it before. 

And as an Arizona resident, I have to issue an "harrumph!" about the single star rating. But thanks for mentioning the saguaro!

Is a pome a kind of berry?  "Berry" has multiple definitions, but I was taught that pomes were different from berries in that berries have a soft parts , while a pome has a leathery endocarp (the area around the seeds).
Drupes, on the other hand, have a hardened endocarp, the pit, like cherries and peaches.

By the way, tomatoes (and eggplants!)  are berries, but strawberries and cherries are not.

Other fun types of fruit, which may be helpful to the crossword creator or solver:
Pepo:  touch exocarp, such as  pumpkins and squash;
Hespiridium: leathery exocarp, like oranges and lemons;
Legume: exocarp splits on two sides: peas and beans.

We'll leave the lecture on nuts, achenes, samaras, follicles, etc. for another time.
For someone reason after reading the first three themed clues my brain went to “ah yes the theme is reviews of national parks as if by bears”
That cirro, asta, tralala corner was a brute. I’d never heard of captain underpants and i don’t know what the thin man is, so that’s a bit of a hurdle.

I'm on a trip solving this one on The High Line in NYC. Such a great narrow urban oasis!

My vote is an amp is a speaker only in live music lingo. As an electrical engineer I would never equate them.

I've never shouted RAH at a sporting event.

However I have no problem with these in today's puzzle.

There's always something new to learn.  The puzzles introduced me to "olio" years ago.  Now it is "cirro" that is added to the list.

Maybe we should organize and write a joint memoir -
"Puzzling Things We've Learned."    :)
I haven’t finished yet. Just came here to say:  I love it when I get the theme halfway through and it helps with other answers. Thank you so much for this fun one.
Of all the state flags I personally think Alaska is the most classy, designed by a 13 (or 14?) year-old Native American boy living in an orphanage to add!

Silent 'T'...oh my gosh...the ah ha moment took some time for that one even though I've seen those types of clues before.

My kitty was at the vet having tests done today, so maybe I can blame it on that...I guess I'm grateful it took so long to figure out the SW corner, it kept my mind occupied. 

To lovely furry friends everywhere...♡
An AMP is not a speaker.  It is something that provides the power to drive a speaker.  Very poor cluing.
Some esoteric references for a Wednesday.
I had to laugh when I read 59 across. How many talk show hosts are dressed? All of them, I hope.

When I was in Japan I was somewhat taken aback by the sight and sound of young pretty diminutive ladies slurping their soup in average restaurants. I believe it’s ok in fine dining there too, so they will probably disagree with 56-A :)

Late post, unrelated to today's puzzle. For no explainable reason, today I was thinking about letter patterns, especially with some that can vary into different words with just a change or two. I had a few finds but here's one of them. 

I wondered about the pattern: 

DE_E_TED

Here are the words that fit that pattern: 

DEFEATED
DEJECTED
DEMENTED
DESERTED
DETESTED
DEFECTED
DETECTED

That seems fairly amazing to me. I might spend more time considering other types of patterns like that. Feel free to join if you want to. 

..

Only about a minute above my Wednesday average!

Well constructed, I found that I caught on to the theme right away but couldn't *quite* get the words right for some reason. Once I got to the bottom of the puzzle and confirmed my hunch I was able to go back through and nail them all :)

Dude, please get back to Xword creating. This was excellent! I loved the Silent T and Ironing clues and as someone who often can't complete Wednesday's this was doable and great fun! Thank  you for starting off my vacation with 4 stars!

This one was lots of fun, and seemed like the perfect Wednesday to me, some fairly easy things, and some I wasn’t familiar with. Just the right amount of crunch. I have only been in 3 of the states, so I guess I beat Sam on that score. I did get a kick out of the Captain Underpants catchphrase, which I got from crosses. I remember my grandsons reading those, but I never asked them for details. I’m so pleased that they love to read, and they still read a lot, actual books, from libraries. God bless them.

Must confess that the afternoon nap has worked its way into the schedule so zoned in and out of this clever thing, but just now getting time to comment.  Was only after seeing, upon completion,  STATE>FLAGS that I caught on to the trick.   Nicely done and thanks..

This was fun! I especially adored the Captain Underpants clue! My son loved Captain Underpants when he was younger so it jolted me back to the sweet times when Dave Pilkey (author) was idolized in our house. He would draw the characters and then write “original artist Dave Pilkey” because even in kindergarten we give credit where credit is due 😂♥️. The Weird Al theme song for the movie still gets stuck in my head. Thank you for the fun puzzle and lovely memories!
This puzzle was too difficult for me. I couldn’t figure out  “rah” “asta” “nuit””olio””sider” and many more answers. The whole puzzle felt forced to me. ✶ wouldn’t recommend.

@Chloe 
I highly doubt too many USonian solvers even knew what many of these state flags vaguely look like (unless they actually happen to live in that particular state), let alone how many stars are on them; that part is just to make you say, “Oh, that’s sort of clever” when you finish the puzzle and read the column. The actual meat of the clues that solve to the state names are all for features that are fairly well known, even for people who don’t live anywhere near the answers, so I don’t see how this should be particularly more challenging for an Anglophone living on the same continent.

How about:
“The forests are so pretty, but I keep getting a sense of déjà vu, as if the whole place were a movie set that’s been reused countless times. Still quite enjoyable.”

“Yawn, another mountain. And why is everyone so obsessed with oil? Would not recommend.”

“This place has everything, from vast lakes to a huge metropolis. Those interested in an educational trip to learn about government will need to prepare to head a bit out of the way, but at least the climate isn’t so muggy.”

“I couldn’t understand a word anyone was saying. Some very nice architecture, though. Also be sure to give the bagels a try.”
I'm Polish and I know exactly zero state flags yet this puzzle was very easy for me: all the clues were so straightforward I did not have to concern myself with the theme at all.
@Andrzej fully agreed! As someone who's frequently sensitive to the US centric clues, these were all common knowledge except for the outfield wall.

Chloe,

Ok, first, heh heh, but what is a Canadian sigh? 

And second, what is up with Canadians reacting “as Canadians” to the puzzle today? Every single day it’s an American (New Yorkian) puzzle. If anything, at one point today I was thinking it was made by an Aussie.

Anyway, just seems your post started a bit of a trend in the comments…

@Chloe & @JohnWM "*sighs in canadian*"

Would that be "aagh-eh"?

@Chloe - Sorry…🍁
 It seems that Nunavut with its single blue star is the only Canadian state/provincial/territorial flag with any stars.

@Steve L 

Having all that knowledge still didn't prevent me from trying "ivied" before "vined" to answer the clue.

@DPaul 

Same here. Fortunately, Laura NYRO quickly appeared and showed me where I had gone wrong.
@Mike I’m glad to see you keeping up your standards (and not flagging), I salute you!

Mike,

For a pun so off colors, you should do pennants.

@HeathieJ 

Yes, it was Aaron from Iowa, and I'll 3rd that recommendation.
@HeathieJ I just finished it on your recommendation and loved it!  Sneaky, sneaky 😄

@Selective Walrus

Pome has frequently been an answer in NYT Xword puzzles.  Over the years, you learn the common culprits.
@Selective Walrus i don't mind obscure words as long as they're crossed with an ordinary word

@Selective Walrus 
Shouldn’t POME be somewhat more easily guessable for a sizable portion of Canadian solvers?

SAGUARO was a gimme once I had two crosses for the U and R. I thought it was a commonly known thing, but apparently I was wrong. Interesting.

POME was indeed difficult, but once I had _ME there it dawned on me what the answer had to be - I suppose because I know a tiny bit of French? Or maybe for some less tangible reason.

NYRO I got entirely from crosses - in fact I didn't notice the answer at all because I never tried to solve the clue.

Selective Walrus,

On behalf of all Canadians - every single one - 


“What?”
@Nick “Pome” is a botanical descriptive. I’m sure botany exists in Canada.

@Howard 

Sure as sarcasm exists in America.
@Pezhead A perfectly suitable assumption, given the phrasing.

@Pezhead wins the internet today!

Well played.

@Okanaganer 

Deb didn't say anything.  Sam writes the Monday through Wednesday writeups.  Deb only does Thursdays and Fridays now.

I've been to all of them except ALASKA.  Maybe if I'd lived in Western Canada, I'd have been there by now, but I'm hoping to rectify this in the next few years.

And of all the others, I've probably been to TENNESSEE the most often. Unless you count driving through GEORGIA on the way to Florida.
@Okanaganer I'd love to go back to the US, as I've been to AZ, NV and TN, but not GA or AK...maybe I'll wait and see how the next few years pan out :|
@Okanaganer Tennessee was the first state I was ever in... in my first state.
@Marshall Walthew Eli's Comin'... a big hit for Three Dog Night.

@Alex Barry 

And then there was And When I Die for Blood Sweat and Tears.
Stoney End, Streisand.

@dutchiris 

I’m sure you’re watching the Warriors game. Hope you caught the Klay tribute 🥲

@Striker

Like a tearful, bittersweet romantic reunion.  I want the Warriors to win, but I wince every time Klay misses a shot.

@dutchiris Did you see the tributes in the pregame show, from Coach Kerr and the players? I’m just a casual fan but that was really touching too. So happy he got the hero’s welcome he deserved. Now let’s hang onto that shrinking lead…

@dutchiris 

Absolutely. Right there with ya.

@bratschegirl 

I also cringed every time Klay made a three.  This was a perfect ending.  We won, but only by one basket.

@dutchiris 
What a game! Klay scored his season high but Steph is just ridiculous.

@Striker

@Charles Nelson Reilly 

Charles, with a name like that, one would think you'd have a bit more knowledge of Hollywood history.

"The Thin Man" was a 1934 novel by Dashiell Hammett that began a series of novels about the detective couple Nick and Nora Charles, featuring their wirehair terrier, ASTA.  

Similar to the James Bond novels by Ian Fleming a generation later, the "Thin Man" books were made into movies in the 30s and 40s, with William Powell and Myrna Loy in the lead roles. It was a hugely popular franchise in its time.

A radio series based on the characters ran in the 40s. A TV series also ran in the late 50s.  

This franchise has produced a lot of entries for the puzzle.  ASTA appears 533 times, practically always as the dog star.  Once in a while, you'll find NORA or THIN MAN as an answer relating to the series, although NICK is usually clued another way.  MYRNA has occasionally been clued to the series as well.  

This is an entry you should remember; it will be back.

@Laurent OK I was mystified by this, too. I put it into a converter, and sure enough CDL = 450. Why, for the love of god?? For that I found a chart. D is the biggest (500), so when C (100) comes before it, that means subtract. Then L is 50 like normal. 500-100 50. I'm super glad we don't count that way anymore.

Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

@Jane Wheelaghan 

Everybody has their own definition of cheating here as there are no officially binding rules of solving puzzles - taking a shortcut or using an engine during the Tour de France would be cheating per cycling's rules, but there is nothing of the sort here, is there? It's all in our heads.

Looking up trivia and the meaning of words I did not know before is not cheating in my book. In the end what is the difference between instantly knowing an actor's name and looking it up? The crosses you get from it are exactly the same, and remembering a name is not a matter of skill or ability, linguistic or otherwise.

Looking up tricky non-trivia clues I do personally consider cheating: when I see I would have to resort to that, I just turn on auto check and forego my gold star.

But that's me. I would never judge another person's standards of solving puzzles by my own.

@Jane Wheelaghan 

I agree with Andrzej's assessment.  I'll add that the crossword world does have the equivalent to the Tour de France: the annual tournament, usually held in Stamford, Connecticut in the spring.  There, the only aid you have in solving is a pencil.  I've never been, but I keep meaning to go, and then I come back to the notion that crossword solving shouldn't be a competition.  (Although the tournament serves as somewhat of a convention, and a lot of the participants on this forum do get to meet IRL.)

That being said, any other time you're solving, you set the rules.  Beginners should think nothing of using whatever aids they need to finish or to enjoy the puzzles to their best ability.  But as you get better, you might choose to set higher goals for solving.  Eventually, you might be good enough to say that anything other than tournament conditions is cheating--for you, that is!

I cut my teeth on crosswords back when the only way you could substantially cheat on crosswords was to do them in a library.  So I never used outside help, and if I couldn't finish a puzzle, I just looked at the answers the next day.  But you do learn more by so-called "cheating", and probably get better faster.

Participating here also helps you improve.  For example, you might read that UTZ has appeared 13 times, all but one since 2010, so you should commit that one to memory...

(I didn't know the rapper, either, but neither did I see him.)

@Steve L 

I knew the rapper.  I guess I've always played by "tournament rules" in that the only things I ever use are my head (sometimes banging on a table) and lots and lots of time....

For me, personally, any kind of lookups are cheating...  But I can't imagine getting away with that if I weren't privileged enough to be a (pretty old) native born American English speaker and resident.

As the other folks said, cheating is a personal definition 'round these parts.

@B Um, no. "Maybe" means "may be", not "may contain". An amp can never be a speaker.

@B 
Colby is 100% correct; a combo AMP may *have* a speaker, but it *is* not one. Not even the "maybe" in the clue can make it valid. The entry is tone deaf.

I don't get you.  It says "speaker on a stage, maybe".  If an amp is on stage, it may contain a speaker, and thus there may be a speaker on the stage.  This seems awfully straightforward.

Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)
I thought the reply on this earlier thread was on point. https://www.nytimes.com/shared/comment/435ve8?rsrc=cshare&smid=url-share

@Barry Ancona 

Agreed.  Just to sum up for those not reading further - the comment is from a professed sound engineer, who refers to the common speaker/amp combo as an amp, as does everyone else in the biz I've read while trying to prove that a speaker and amp are not the same thing.  It is, especially to those who use them.  And they're on stage.

@B "it may contain a speaker, and thus there may be a speaker on the stage." "Be" and "contain" are not synonyms. The clue says "Speaker on stage, maybe".  That means that the answer for this space IS (not contains) an example of a speaker on stage. Valid answers might be orator, lecturer, woofer, tweeter, etc. An amp, however, is never a speaker in any circumstance, so the clue cannot describe its answer and is therefore invalid.

@Colby Hawkins 

But, everyone on the net in the biz, it seems, uses "amp" to refer to the amp/speaker combo, not just the amp.  I saw sound engineering discussions about aiming "amps" in different directions and no one batted an eye.  They're talking about the speakers. I was initially skeptical, but now I'm convinced the clue is fine.

I think the constructor hit the mark, misdirection was good. It is ultimately not about making a speaker (as orator) an amplifier. To turn it up to eleven;  sure it’s about that housed product that could be on a stage that is also a sound emitting device. You know music amps and combo amps are just called amps in everyday use. In consumer electronics that wouldn't be the case, amplified speakers would generally not be referred to as amps. 

In another case a similar but unamplified clue arrangement could be validly devised for "monitor" and "speaker on a stage”, I don’t know what kind of feedback that would get.

@Colby Hawkins The thing that is on the stage, that functions as a speaker, that contains the amplifier part and the speaker part and other parts,—is commonly referred to as an "amp". Just like "CPU" can be used to refer to a whole computer.

@Grant 
A speaker needs power to produce sound.  That power can be in a separate device, or incorporated in the same unit.  When they're combined in a single box, it contains both the speaker and the power supply.  You can call that device a "powered speaker".  I call it an "amp".  I'd say that "maybe" in the clue is expansive enough to cover the situation.  It is, after all, just a clue.  Maybe we disagree.

@Byron I would definitely say suffix - “sider” adjusts the “Sydney” to indicate someone who lives there, and can’t be used by itself, which to me feels suffix and not compound noun. As a former Sydneysider I did instantly come here to see how many people had heard of it before, and I am unsure whether I’m surprised by the frequency !

@Bryony

Respectfully, I think “sider” is the noun “side” with the modifying suffix “er” to make it a description of a person or actor. 

So I’d analogize it more to the construction of “downtown” (which is clearly a compound noun) which can be modified to mean somebody who’s from there by adding that “er” suffix — downtowner (or uptowner or midtowner). 

So, for me, the suffix is the “er”(or “or”) which is a very common suffix in English. 

I also presume one could grammatically say, “I was born Sydneyside” in the same way Americans refer to “Stateside” to refer to America when they’re elsewhere.
